Trichoderma reesei QM6a is a filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Trichoderma. It is a well-known industrial microorganism due to its ability to produce a wide range of cellulolytic and hemicellulolytic enzymes, which are essential for the degradation of plant cell wall polysaccharides.

The QM6a strain of T. reesei is a mutant strain that was initially isolated from soil samples collected in the Solomon Islands during World War II. This strain has been extensively studied and optimized for industrial-scale enzyme production.

T. reesei QM6a is a mesophilic fungus, meaning it thrives in moderate temperature ranges, typically between 25°C to 35°C. It is a fast-growing organism that can produce a large biomass in a relatively short period of time.

The fungus produces a complex set of cellulases, hemicellulases, and other auxiliary enzymes that work synergistically to break down cellulose and hemicellulose, the main components of plant cell walls. These enzymes have a wide range of applications in various industries, such as biofuel production, paper and pulp processing, textile manufacturing, and animal feed production.

T. reesei QM6a is widely used as a model organism for the study of fungal enzyme production and regulation, as well as for the development of improved strains through genetic engineering and directed evolution techniques.
